title: Between 1 April 2018 and 31 March 2019, will an armed group from Afghanistan engage in a campaign that systematically kills 1,000 or more civilians in Afghanistan?
preds:

Unlikey, that there will be anything that kills 1000 or more civilians.

The stage is set with the Co Executives who themselves came to power among voting irregularities, The President sees national IDs as a way to protect elections and the other sees a way to rig elections, so campaign season could get violent.
Afghan President Launches Controversial National ID Card
By Ayaz Gul May 03, 2018 Afghan President Ashraf Ghani launched long-delayed electronic citizen ID cards Thursday, but his governing partner, Chief Executive Abdullah Abdullah, boycotted the ceremony and questioned the legitimacy and timing of the process. The president and first lady Rula Ghani, along with several top officials, received their ID cards, locally known as "e-tazkiras," marking the formal rollout at a special ceremony in Kabul. The existing national ID cards are made of paper and, officials say, are highly prone to tampering and fraud. President Ghani reiterated those concerns at Thursday's ceremony. "An important reason for launching this card is that terrorists have taken advantage of the paper ID card, endangering security of all our countrymen, and protecting lives and property of Afghans is the fundamental responsibility of the government," Ghani said. Ghani also said the digitized national ID card is an essential and crucial step toward better governance, economic development, transparency and delivery of services. Not everyone is happy with the electronic card. The document identifies its holder as "Afghan," which some critics say is used to denote the country's majority ethnic Pashtuns. However, President Ghani, an ethnic Pashtun, defended the card, saying it represents every Afghan ethnic group. Some within the Dari-speaking Tajiks, the country's second largest ethnic group, are leading the opposition to the new ID cards. Shortly after Ghani introduced the digitized cards, Chief Executive Abdullah, also a Tajik, addressed a news conference to reiterate his reservations and rejected what he said was a one-sided decision. "The reason I have not participated in distribution of e-tazkiras is that I know this process lacks legitimacy and support from the Afghan people... It will lead to to crisis and more problems," Abdullah warned. Abdullah, however, went on to say he was not among those questioning the use of the term "Afghan" on the new card. "I as an Afghan am proud of my identity as a Muslim and Afghan. I know there are individuals and groups that are preaching the message that I am against certain words being mentioned in e-tazkira. This is completely false." Abdullah explained he was not opposed to electronic ID cards for Afghans but the timing of its launching was not right. President Ghani had intended to enable Afghans to use e-tazkira cards in the October 20 parliamentary and district council elections to deter fraud and rigging. But the plan was abandoned in the wake of technical delays and political differences over including ethnicity and nationality on the card. Afghan voters will be using the old paper cards for the October polls.

The UN reports "record high levels" of civilian casualties for the first quarter of 2018. Per the report, there were 763 deaths so far in Afghanistan from January 1 to March 31 attributed to the Afghan government and "anti government elements" (511 deaths)  which includes  IS and the Taliban. The Taliban alone were responsible for half of the "anti-government elements" deaths.   https://unama.unmissions.org/latest-un-update-records-continuing-record-high-levels-civilian-casualties-2018

Just in 2016 alone, nearly 20,000 non-combatant fatalities resulted from terrorist attacks in Afghanistan. While terrorism is typically considered indiscriminate killing rather than systematic, this number speaks to the significant violence and threat to life that Afghan civilians face in a given year. The Taliban alone have full control of 4% of the country and are a strong and threatening presence in another 66% (http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-42863116). The Taliban regularly carries out organized and target attacks against Afghan government officials, military, and police. While larger attacks usually result in dozens to a hundred fatalities, these attacks happen frequently, and added together those numbers could unfortunately climb to 1,000 very quickly. The posing of this question means that this killing of 1000 civilians could be carried out by a variety of actors, not just the Taliban, making it even more likely to occur by March 2019.  Sources: https://www.start.umd.edu/pubs/START_MassCasualtyExplosivesAttacksIraqAfghanistan_BackgroundReport_June2017.pdf
http://www.bbc.com/news/world-asia-42863116
The Taliban and similar terrorist groups are likely to attack. If their efforts are well coordinated, it is 30% likely that more than 1000 victims could be killed.
